bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 5, 1879

div1.p: Reed has photographs of his wife and son, and asks if they remember him. He gives news of their acquaintances and his Spanish studies.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 5, 1879
div1.p:
Mantee has
just been to his trunk and had a “weal”
nice long talk with his darlings, and
now he is going to “wite” to them all
about it- Papa wants to take back
what he said in his last letter about
his darling boy's picture- It is really
much better than I thought it was-
I find that by holding it away
about two feet that it comes
out much more clearly and dist-
-inctly, and there father sees the
sweetest little boy with the
cutest and most cunning look
imaginable. Papa just goes to
his trunk, generally twice a day,
& then he takes out his darling
wife's & boy's photograph and he
has the greatest talk with
them you ever heard- genuine
baby-talk, and he intersperses his
talk with many kisses for both
of them; but most of them & the swee-
-test ones are always reserved
for mother. For however much papa
loves his darling Laurie (& he knows
he loves him as much as any fa-
-ther can love a child,) yet there is
a love for mama, for my darling
Emilie, my own precious wife,
my only lovie, which as far sur-
-passes it as the day excels the
night! And the two together he loves, a thous
-and times better than his own
life! The last thing thought at night, the
first on the morrow, always
is of his loved ones- There
are so many things here to
remind papa of mama & son.
The old house & kitchen has
a thousand sweet recollections
The old kitchen, I must confess
dovie, has some recollections
that are not pleasant ones-
To think that my poor little dar-
ling had to go into that horrid
old kitchen & work like a dog!
Oh, I wish it had never been
necessary; for my poor, precious
Emilie had so many other labors
that were sufficiently disagree-
-able to perform, that she might
have been spared this- But
lovie, dear, did not your old man-
-tee help you all he could? and
did he not nurse you tenderly,
faithfully when you were sick?
And if he sometimes spoke crossly
to you, did he not always beg his
little wifie's pardon & seal it
with a kiss? Yes! my darling,
you know he always hastened
to seek forgiveness- The old “casa
grande” too, often brings to my
thoughts my darling wife and boy-
Papa remembers how sick his
poor, sweet wifie was & how pa-
-tiently she bore it all, and remem-
-bering this, he could never see his
precious brought to bed again, ex-
-cept it should be her own wish!
Now, darling, it isnt every husband
who is so thoughtful of his wife's
welfare, & who for her sake, would
have made such a promise- Noth-
-ing but love, of the purest kind,
could cause a husband to so
promise- But there is nothing that
I would not do, for your comfort
and happiness, my own pretty Em-
-ilie! Husband would bear & bear
willingly every pain that his
precious darling has to suffer, if
it were possible. Although he
occasionally he must have his
joke about papa's little girl,
mother knows that he is only
jesting -- and she knows how good
papa has been for a long
time- Love your darling heart,
there's no man loves his wife more
than I do, & who would do more for
his precious darling than your ugly
old mantee!
(“Boodigs”!)
If papa ever takes a walk
out past the Hospital, he thinks
of his darling wife, who always
would stop to gather seed from
some wild flowers and mantee
wasn't always willing to stop,
and for this he is very sorry now-
If he walks up & down on the long
walk in front of the quarters, he
always thinks of mother, & how
she used to get her darling little
(I mean big) legs & petticoats all
full of dust -- old apache dust, -- that
always made my the little “oomsey”
so mad. Well, the old dust is just
as bad still, lovie, & gets in old
mantee's pants a heap, but he
doesn't brush it out one bit-
he just leaves it for the Pope's
Nuncio to wrestle over- I don't
black shoes nowadays, either, my
lovie; nor sweep either, nor carry
out dirty water either! “I'se jest”
plays the gentleman all the time!
And what makes me so much hap-
-pier is that my precious Emilie
doesn't have to gather wild flowers
now, but has the genuine domes-
-ticated article to afford her en-
-joyment- How you must fairlly fairly
revel in them, my lovie- Do you
never select some sweet blossom
& wear it for poor old mantee? You
must do so, lovie, you hear? Mantee
would have gathered the wild
flowers, as directed by his little
darling, but the rains haven't
yet descended and there isn't
a flower to be seen anywhere.
The ivy, darling, Mrs. Harrison
was going to return as soon as
I got back, but I told her to
keep it- It sits on the front
porch & looks very beautiful- I
always see it three times a day
& never fail to think of my lovie
when I pass. “Boodigs”! Lovie!
Sunday afternoon- 6th July- The mail
has arrived and a mighty sweet
letter from you, my prettie lovie,
all written across, back & forth,
and all very sweet to old mantee's
heart- So papa's little Laurie has
not yet forgotten the word “papa”:
Love his precious little life, don't
let him forget his own precious
daddie, my darling wife! I tell
you old mantee almost had
the “blues” after getting your
letter- He was so anxious to
see his precious darlings, and
“finks” its so hard to have to be
separated from them for so long
a time- He'll “dit wight madsig,”
if they don't make haste & let
him “tome” East! I guess, while
I am writing this, my little lovie
is in Harrisonburg, and has been
for almost a week- Oh! if old
“Teesigon” was only there, what
times we could have! Romping
about the house -- & yard -- Rolling
& tumbling in the grass -- play-
ing croquet -- eating green
apples -- having the “pelly”ache--
singing -- eating -- sleeping -- read-
ing, and a hundred other innocent
enjoyments! Well I don't intend
to have the “blues” anyway- I
won't have them! For I have
got a good position, with a suf-
-ficient salary to live comfortably,
and the prettiest boy and the dear-
-est, sweetest, best little wife,
that ever man had, and I just
intend to thank Heaven (which
I do daily,) and be satisfied! And
as “oomantee” has a husband
who doesn't drink, gamble or
steal, she must be satisfied too,
& not get discouraged at the
long separation from her ugly
old mantee- Love your life, if
I could see you this moment, I
would bite your darling nose clean
off -- “you'se so feetning”! “Boodigs”!
Monday morning 7th. How is darling
wifie and “bad daddies” this mor-
ning! what are papa's loves
doing to pass away their time?
Are they “finking” any of
old papa way out in “Aridonie”?
Did they have a pleasant journey
from Norfolk to Harrisonburg,
& stop in Washington and have a
peep at all the pretty things?
what does Grandma Reed have
to say about papa's Laurie?
doesn't she think he is the pret-
tiest finest boy that she ever
saw? and doesn't little Sister
Annie think the same? By the way,
lovie, if Miss Annie Samuels is
at Ma's, you must give her
my Kindest regards- She is a
very nice lady and very intell-
igent- I think Ma wrote me
that she was teaching Annie.
Before I forget it, my darling,
I have just read in a Tucson
paper an account of the mar-
-riage of Rev. Mr Anderson to
Miss Sophie Hudson -- the char-
-ming & beautiful Miss Sophie
whom you remember as al-
-ways being so solicitous
about the north-east corner
of the hem of her garment, and
who used to gaze so intently,
with mouth ajar, when Chap-
-lain Nash was talking!
They had a “tearing” old time, and
“all went merry as a marriage
bell” -- so the paper says- The most
distinguished citizens of Tucson
with their Señoras graced the
scene, and after partaking of
a “bountiful collation,” the hap-
-py pair left on a bridal
tour to Colorado. “One by one
the roses fade” &c- The “belles”
of Tucson are gradually being
thinned out- Miss Jannison
will probably go next- You
astonished me by saying that
Miss Lou U. had Uriah Jr.
for a sweetheart! much suc-
-cess to her! and to him too!
And isn't Miss Nellie Vaughan
married yet? Land alive!
How many beaus has she had!
I should think the old man
would make her take a husband
unto herself, just to get rid
of so many well-dressed fel-
lows lounging about the prem-
ises! Does Miss Alice still en-
-joy the state of “single blessed-
-ness”? I'll bet five dollars that
C. Reed, Esq- attorney at Law, will
court that “gal” yet! whether
he will get her or not I don't
know- I think he'd stand a chance.
The cravat and gloves came safe-
ly to hand by yesterday's mail,
my lovie, and I am so much
obliged to my little Emilie for
sending them. The gloves are
very nice & give me the appear-
-ance of quite a “swell-” The cra-
vat is becoming too and gives
me the air of considerable respec-
-tability- It is the first one that
I have worn since my return
from Otero- But, lovie dear, what
did you send me a black
cravat for? Don't you know that
you fell in love with me
when I was wearing a flam-
-ing blue one! in church at
Murfreesboro! Have you for-
-gotten that circumstance, my
sweet wifie? Hereafter remem-
-ber that my favorite colors
are a “cerulean sky”, a “daz-
-zling pink” or a “subdued
solferino”- but never a black!
“Boodigs”! Eat'em up! Kiss
me forty times, you darling wifie-
no more until to-morrow- Have
got to study lots of Spanish
to-day-
